description: Borrowed from Middle French pontife, from Latin pontifex. Doublet of pontifex.

entries.meaning: (historical, Ancient Rome) A member of the most illustrious of the colleges of priests of the Roman religion, the College of Pontiffs; a pontifex. [from 17th c.]
A bishop of the early Church; now specifically, the Pope. [from 16th c.]
examples: In several respects John turned out to be an unexpected figure as supreme pontiff.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) Any chief figure or leader of a religion. [from 16th c.]
